VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows: The facility has
submitted one corrective action plan during this reporting period. This CAP was in
response to the special investigation (2025SIC0000294) with a finding of non-
compliance that is requiring a corrective action plan. The finding of non-
compliance involves a violation of COF Rule 400.10107 (Repeat Violation) with
an allegation of a specific staff member allowing youth to watch pornography on a
television in their Pod. The corrective action plan involved the following action
steps. The staff involved was terminated from employment which is verified by
documentation from the HR department. The Administrator oversaw the removal
of all “smart” televisions from the facility and the replacement of “dumb”
televisions which will be located so what is being viewed can be seen by the
cameras on the Pods. This will be verified by on-site review by licensing. All staff
are required to attend an updated Mandated reporter training at an all-staff
meeting. Any staff not able to attend will be required to attend individual
Mandated reporter training. To verify staff’s involvement in the training a sign-in
sheet will be used and provided. The final action step involves the development
of a new policy outlining a way to ensure staff fully understand their
responsibilities in being a mandated report. Once this policy is developed a copy
will be sent to licensing and incorporated in the training. At the time of this review,
there has not been adequate time to begin evaluating the CAP.

Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Not Applicable.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported a belief they are supported by administration and are
receiving the appropriate amount of training to help deal with the issues presented
by youth. They also reported knowing the different aspects of their positions and
what is required to keep the youth safe and well cared for. Staff reported what they
believed would be improvements at the facility such as providing training skills for
the youth beyond just normal school subjects.
All youth interviewed (detention and treatment) at the facility reported feeling safe
and well cared for by the staff. They also reported staff are attentive to their needs
and willing to listen to issues they present. Those in the treatment program
reported the program is helping them learn what they need to change to avoid
further law enforcement contacts, and each shared the specific things they are
working on to change. The Treatment youth also reported being provided
individual and group therapy weekly. The detention youth all reported doing well
and reported having goals to get out and avoid a return. The detention youth
reported having access to therapy services when requested.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a multi-level structure in excellent shape and condition. It appears to be
well maintained and appropriately furnished. All plumbing was in working order
and the building was well heated. The menu and other required items were posted
throughout the facility. Emergency drills and room check logs were reviewed and
appropriate. All cleaning supplies were locked away from the youth. The kitchen
was well stocked and there was a significant amount of food (fresh, frozen, and dry
goods) available. Fire extinguishers were up to date.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
